title: Bacterial Meningitis
scope: ** Acute community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults. Covers emergency empiric antibiotics, dexamethasone adjunctive therapy, LP and CSF analysis, targeted therapy by organism, and complications management. Excludes viral meningitis, fungal meningitis, TB meningitis, healthcare-associated/post-surgical meningitis, and pediatric meningitis.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: MUST be drawn BEFORE antibiotics but do NOT delay antibiotics to obtain; positive in 50-70% of bacterial meningitis
Leukocytosis with left shift; baseline; thrombocytopenia (DIC risk)
Electrolytes (SIADH: hyponatremia), renal/hepatic function for antibiotic dosing
Highly sensitive for bacterial infection; helps distinguish bacterial from viral meningitis (>0.5 strongly suggests bacterial)
Inflammatory marker; helps monitor treatment response
Sepsis assessment; elevated in bacterial meningitis

Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; DIC: elevated PT/aPTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Potential need for blood products (DIC, sepsis)

Extended Workup.target: Urine osm >100, urine Na >40 in SIADH

Extended Workup.rationale: Immunocompromise affects empiric coverage and differential
Terminal complement deficiency predisposes to recurrent Neisseria meningitidis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Culture-negative meningitis; prior antibiotic exposure; atypical organisms
Recurrent meningitis: skull base fracture, CSF leak, sinusitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in bacterial meningitis; monitor for elevated ICP
Lumbar Puncture.target: Typically 200-500 mm H2O (normal <200); markedly elevated suggests edema/hydrocephalus

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Bacterial: neutrophilic pleocytosis; tube 1 vs 4 differentiates traumatic tap
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC >1000 cells/µL with >80% neutrophils (bacterial); WBC 100-10,000 typical

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF:serum ratio <0.4 strongly suggests bacterial meningitis
Rapid identification; positive in 60-90% of untreated bacterial meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Organisms identified (gram-positive diplococci = pneumococcus; gram-negative diplococci = meningococcus; gram-positive rods = Listeria; gram-negative rods = E. coli/Haemophilus)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Gold standard for organism identification and antibiotic sensitivities; may be negative after antibiotics
Rapid multiplex PCR (14 pathogens in ~1 hour); especially valuable if prior antibiotics given
Lumbar Puncture.target: Identifies E. coli K1, H. influenzae, L. monocytogenes, N. meningitidis, S. agalactiae, S. pneumoniae, plus viruses (HSV, enterovirus, VZV, etc.) and Cryptococcus

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF lactate >3.5 mmol/L highly suggestive of bacterial (sensitivity ~93%, specificity ~96%); useful post-antibiotics when cultures may be negative
Exclude concurrent HSV encephalitis; do not miss treatable cause
If TB meningitis suspected (subacute, basilar enhancement, HIV)

Essential/First-line.timing: ONLY if LP delay indications present (see below). Do NOT delay antibiotics for CT. CT BEFORE LP only if: immunocompromised, history of CNS disease, new seizure, papilledema, altered consciousness (GCS <10), focal neurologic deficit
Essential/First-line.target: Mass effect, hydrocephalus, abscess, herniation risk

Extended.target: Meningeal enhancement, abscess, empyema, cerebritis, venous sinus thrombosis, hydrocephalus

Extended.timing: If cerebral venous thrombosis suspected (persistent headache, focal signs, seizures)
If S. aureus or endocarditis suspected

If signs of elevated ICP, declining consciousness despite treatment

Acute/Emergent — Empiric Therapy.item: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose) 0.15 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h x 4 days (typically 10 mg IV q6h). MUST be given BEFORE or simultaneously with first antibiotic dose. Greatest benefit for S. pneumoniae (reduces mortality and hearing loss). Discontinue if organism is NOT S. pneumoniae (some centers continue regardless)

Referrals & Consults.indication: All bacterial meningitis; antibiotic optimization; complicated cases
Seizures, altered consciousness, focal deficits, ICP management
Hydrocephalus (EVD), brain abscess, subdural empyema, ICP management
Septic shock, respiratory failure, DIC, ICP management
Recurrent meningitis (CSF leak), concurrent sinusitis/mastoiditis source
Hearing assessment before discharge (hearing loss in up to 30% S. pneumoniae)
Meningococcal meningitis — mandatory reporting; contact tracing and prophylaxis
Swallowing assessment if altered consciousness; cognitive assessment
Severe cases with poor prognosis; goals of care

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if: worsening headache, fever recurrence, new confusion, seizure, neck stiffness, rash, vision changes
Complete full antibiotic course (do NOT stop early even if feeling better)
Hearing test recommended 2-4 weeks after discharge
Vaccination: pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccines after recovery if not previously immunized
Close contacts should receive prophylactic antibiotics if N. meningitidis (public health will coordinate)
Follow-up with infectious disease and neurology in 2-4 weeks
Report any new neurologic symptoms (hearing loss, balance problems, cognitive changes)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV20 or PCV15 + PPSV23) if not previously completed
Meningococcal vaccination (MenACWY + MenB) for at-risk groups
Smoking cessation (upper respiratory tract colonization risk)
Splenectomy patients: ensure vaccinated (encapsulated organism risk)
Complement-deficient patients: meningococcal vaccination and booster schedule
Hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette education
Skull base fracture/CSF leak patients: surgical repair to prevent recurrence

differential.features: Less toxic; CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose, mildly elevated protein; self-limited
differential.tests: CSF cell count (lymphocytes), normal glucose, BioFire ME panel (enterovirus most common), procalcitonin low

differential.features: Encephalitis (confusion, personality change, seizures, focal signs); temporal lobe involvement
differential.tests: MRI (temporal T2/FLAIR), CSF HSV PCR, EEG (PLEDs)

differential.features: Subacute (weeks), basilar meningitis, cranial neuropathies, HIV risk; CSF: lymphocytic, low glucose, very high protein
differential.tests: AFB smear/culture, TB PCR (GeneXpert), adenosine deaminase (ADA), chest X-ray (miliary pattern), PPD/IGRA

differential.features: Subacute/chronic; immunocompromised (HIV CD4 <100); headache predominant; minimal CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: CSF cryptococcal antigen (CrAg), India ink, fungal culture

differential.features: Thunderclap headache; meningismus; NOT febrile initially; xanthochromia
differential.tests: CT head (blood), CSF RBC (tube 1 = tube 4), xanthochromia

differential.features: Focal deficits; fever + headache + focal signs (triad); subacute; seizures
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (ring-enhancing lesion with restricted diffusion), CT with contrast

differential.features: Post-sinusitis/otitis; rapid deterioration; focal deficits; seizures
Subacute onset; psychiatric symptoms; seizures; young women; no fever initially
differential.tests: Autoimmune antibody panel (serum + CSF); MRI; EEG

differential.features: NSAID, IVIG, TMP-SMX, isoniazid exposure; self-limited after drug withdrawal
differential.tests: Drug history; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis; sterile cultures; resolves with drug removal

differential.features: Subacute; cranial neuropathies; known malignancy; CSF: low glucose, elevated protein, positive cytology
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3 for sensitivity); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement)

differential.features: Chronic headache; cranial neuropathies (CN VII); hilar adenopathy; ACE level
differential.tests: Chest CT; serum ACE; CSF ACE; biopsy

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h then q2-4h; more frequent if declining
monitoring.action: If GCS declining: STAT CT, ICP assessment, consider EVD
If persistent fever >72h: repeat cultures, imaging for abscess/empyema, drug fever, new infection

monitoring.frequency: q1h if sepsis; q4h if stable

monitoring.action: If <130: SIADH likely → fluid restriction (1-1.2 L/day); if <120: 3% saline
Adjust antibiotics if rising; vancomycin nephrotoxicity

monitoring.frequency: Before 4th dose; then q24-48h until stable

monitoring.action: If platelets dropping: DIC panel; if WBC not improving: reassess antibiotics
FFP for INR >1.5; cryoprecipitate for fibrinogen <100; platelet transfusion if <50K with bleeding
If not declining by day 3-5: reassess; repeat LP; imaging

monitoring.frequency: Clinical observation; cEEG if altered consciousness
monitoring.action: Levetiracetam load; if refractory → status epilepticus protocol
Audiology referral; hearing aid evaluation if deficit
Tiered ICP management: CSF drainage, osmotherapy, sedation

disposition.criteria: Never discharge directly from ED with suspected bacterial meningitis. Discharge from hospital when: afebrile ≥48h, improving neurologic exam, able to take oral medications (IV-to-PO switch criteria met for some organisms), adequate outpatient IV access if completing IV course, reliable follow-up
Hemodynamically stable; GCS ≥13; no respiratory compromise; no DIC; no seizures
Septic shock; GCS <13 or declining; respiratory failure; DIC; refractory seizures; signs of elevated ICP; meningococcemia with purpura fulminans; need for vasopressors
Need for neurosurgery (abscess, empyema, EVD); need for neuro-ICU expertise not available
